qas.question: Why is mercury the better option for liquid used in a Hydrostatic gauge?

answers.text: its high density and low vapour pressure

qas.question: What is a vertical column of liquid in a tube which has different pressures at each end called?
What is a hydrostatic gauge used for?

answers.text: measure pressures ranging from 1 torr (100 Pa) to above atmospheric

qas.question: Why is the McLeod gauge special?

answers.text: can measure vacuums as high as 10−6 torr

qas.question: An indirect measurement of pressure is most often calibrated by what?
What is the level of mercury in the air calibrated by?
What is the density level of mercury in the air?
What is used to measure mercury in the air?
What is the lowest amount of mercury that can be measured in the air?
What measurements are used to measure mercury in the air?

context: <a1_0>Hydrostatic gauges<a1_0/> (such as the mercury column manometer) consist of a vertical column of liquid in a tube whose ends are exposed to different pressures. The column will rise or fall until its weight is in equilibrium with the pressure differential between the two ends of the tube. The simplest design is a closed-end U-shaped tube, one side of which is connected to the region of interest. Any fluid can be used, but mercury is preferred for <a0_0>its high density and low vapour pressure<a0_0/>. Simple hydrostatic gauges can <a2_0>measure pressures ranging from <b8_0>1 torr (100 Pa)<b8_0/> to above atmospheric<a2_0/>. An important variation is <b7_0>the McLeod gauge<b7_0/> which isolates a known volume of vacuum and compresses it to multiply the height variation of the liquid column. The McLeod gauge <a3_0>can measure vacuums as high as <b6_0>10−6 torr<a3_0/> (0.1 mPa)<b6_0/>, which is the lowest direct measurement of pressure that is possible with current technology. Other vacuum gauges can measure lower pressures, but only indirectly by measurement of other pressure-controlled properties. These <b9_0>indirect measurements<b9_0/> must be calibrated via <b5_0>a direct measurement<b5_0/>, most commonly a <a4_0>McLeod gauge<a4_0/>.
